  "article_text": [
    "since the introduction of @xmath4-algebras of groupoids , in the late 1970 s , several classes of @xmath4-algebras have been given groupoid models .",
    "one such class is the class of graph @xmath4-algebras .    in their paper @xcite , kumjian , pask , raeburn and renault associated to each",
    "locally finite directed graph @xmath5 a locally compact groupoid @xmath6 , and showed that its groupoid @xmath4-algebra @xmath7 is the universal @xmath4-algebra generated by families of partial isometries satisfying the cuntz - krieger relations determined by @xmath5 . in @xcite , spielberg constructed a locally compact groupoid @xmath6 associated to a general graph @xmath5 and generalized the result to a general directed graph .",
    "we refer to @xcite for the detail theory of topological groupoids and their @xmath4-algebras .    a directed graph @xmath8 consists of a countable set @xmath9 of vertices and @xmath10 of edges , and maps @xmath11 identifying the origin ( source ) and the terminus ( range ) of each edge . for the purposes of this discussion",
    "it is sufficient to consider row  finite graphs with no sinks .    for the moment , let @xmath12 be a bundle of of row  finite directed trees with no sinks , that is a disjoint union of trees that have no sinks or infinite emitters , i.e. , no singular vertices .",
    "we denote the set of finite paths of @xmath12 by @xmath13 and the set of infinite paths by @xmath14 .    for each @xmath15 , define @xmath16 for @xmath17 ,",
    "we see that : @xmath18 it is fairly easy to see that :    the cylinder sets @xmath19 form a base of compact open sets for a locally compact , totally disconnected , hausdorff topology of @xmath14 .",
    "we want to define a groupoid that has @xmath14 as a unit space . for @xmath20 , and @xmath21 ,",
    "@xmath22 is shift equivalent to @xmath23 with lag @xmath24 _ and write @xmath25 , if there exists @xmath26 such that @xmath27 .",
    "it is not difficult to see that shift equivalence is an equivalence relation .",
    "[ def.501 ] let @xmath28 . for pairs in @xmath29",
    ", we define @xmath30 for arbitrary @xmath31 , we define @xmath32    with the operations and , and source and range maps @xmath33 given by @xmath34 is a groupoid with unit space @xmath14 .    for @xmath35 , with @xmath36 ,",
    "define @xmath37 , where @xmath38 denotes the length of the path @xmath39 .",
    "the sets @xmath40 make @xmath6 a locally compact @xmath41-discrete groupoid with ( topological ) unit space equal to @xmath14 .",
    "now let @xmath5 be a directed graph .",
    "we form a graph whose vertices are the paths of @xmath5 and edges are ( ordered ) pairs of paths as follows :    let @xmath42 denote the following graph :    @xmath43    @xmath44    @xmath45 .",
    "the following lemma , due to spielberg @xcite , is straightforward .",
    "[ lemm.sp24 ] ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 2.4 ) @xmath42 is a bundle of trees .",
    "notice that if @xmath5 is a row  finite graph with no sinks , then @xmath42 is a bundle of row  finite trees with no sinks .    if @xmath46 is the groupoid obtained as in definition [ def.501 ] , where @xmath42 plays the role of @xmath12 then , in @xcite spielberg showed , in its full generality , that the graph @xmath4-algebra of @xmath5 is equal to the @xmath4-algebra of the groupoid @xmath46",
    "we refer to @xcite , for readers interested in the general construction and the proof .",
    "we now examine the @xmath4-algebra @xmath47 , which is the @xmath4-algebra of the graph @xmath48_a \\ar@(ru , ul)[]_b}\\ ] ] denoting the vertex of @xmath5 by 0 and the edges of @xmath5 by @xmath49 and @xmath50 , as shown in the graph , the vertices of @xmath42 are @xmath51 etc . and the graph @xmath42 is the binary tree .",
    "take a typical path @xmath39 of @xmath5 , say @xmath52 .",
    "writing @xmath53 as 3 and @xmath54 as @xmath55 , etc .",
    "we can write @xmath39 as @xmath56 which is an element of @xmath57 ( the free product of two copies of @xmath58 ) .",
    "in other words , the set of vertices of @xmath42 is @xmath59 , where @xmath60 , and the vertex 0 is the empty word .",
    "the elements of @xmath61 are the infinite sequence of @xmath62 s and @xmath63 s , where @xmath64 and @xmath65 .    motivated by this construction",
    ", we wish to explore the @xmath4-algebra of the case when @xmath1 is an ordered abelian group , and @xmath3 is the free product of two copies of @xmath66 . in this paper",
    "we study the special case when @xmath67 endowed with the lexicographic ordering , where @xmath68 .",
    "the paper is organized as follows . in section 2",
    "we develop the topology of the @xmath69-tree . in section 3",
    "we build the @xmath4-algebra of the @xmath69-tree by first building the groupoid @xmath6 in a fashion similar to that of the graph groupoid . in section 4 , by explicitly exploring the partial isometries generating the @xmath4-algebra , we give a detailed description of the @xmath4-algebra . in section 5 ,",
    "we look at the crossed product of the @xmath4-algebra by the gauge action and study the fixed - point algebra . finally in section 6 we provide classification of the @xmath4-algebra .",
    "we prove that the @xmath4-algebra is simple , purely infinite , nuclear and classifiable .",
    "i am deeply indebted to jack spielberg without whom none of this would have been possible .",
    "i also wish to thank mark tomforde for many helpful discussions and for providing material when i could not find them otherwise .",

    "[ in fact , since @xmath494 , there are at most @xmath63 of them to choose from . ]    to prove that @xmath401 is an af algebra , we start with a finite subset @xmath229 of the generating set @xmath495 and show that there is a finite dimensional @xmath4-subalgebra of @xmath401 that contains the set @xmath229 .",
    "[ thm.501 ] @xmath401 is an af algebra .",
    "suppose that @xmath496 is a ( finite ) subset of the generating set of @xmath401 .",

    "consider the set @xmath525_{c",
    "\\cap d}:pc , qd \\in \\mathcal{c } \\text { and } p = p_\\alpha , q = q_\\alpha , 1 \\leq \\alpha \\leq s\\}.\\ ] ] since @xmath502 is a finite collection , this collection is finite too .",
    "we will prove that @xmath526 is pairwise disjoint .",

    "kirchberg - phillips classification theorem states that simple , unital , purely infinite , and nuclear @xmath4-algebras are classified by their @xmath774-theory @xcite . in the continuation of this project ,",

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> let @xmath0 with lexicographic ordering . </S>",
    "<S> @xmath1 is a totally ordered group . </S>",
    "<S> let @xmath2 . </S>",
    "<S> then @xmath3 is a @xmath1-tree . </S>",
    "<S> analogous to the construction of graph @xmath4-algebras , we form a groupoid whose unit space is the space of ends of the tree . </S>",
    "<S> the @xmath4-algebra of the @xmath1-tree is defined as the @xmath4-algebra of this groupoid . </S>",
    "<S> we prove some properties of this @xmath4-algebra . </S>"
  ]
